functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: Who are the protagonists of the top five Studio Ghibli movies with the highest Rotten Tomatoes ratings?
Who are the protagonists of the top five Studio Ghibli movies with the highest Rotten Tomatoes ratings?

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Studio Ghibli</title>
<fragment>

Five of the studio's films are among the ten highest-grossing anime feature films made in Japan. *Spirited Away* is second, grossing 31.68 billion yen in Japan and over US$380 million worldwide; and *Princess Mononoke* is fourth, grossing 20.18 billion yen. Three of their films have won the Animage Grand Prix award, four have won the Japan Academy Prize for Animation of the Year, and five have received Academy Award nominations. *Spirited Away* won the 2002 Golden Bear and the 2003 Academy Award for Best Animated Feature.[8]


On August 3, 2014, Studio Ghibli temporarily suspended production following Miyazaki's retirement. In February 2017, Suzuki announced that Miyazaki had come out of retirement to direct a new feature film, *The Boy and the Heron* (2023).[9][10] In September 2023, Nippon TV announced that Studio Ghibli would become a unit of Nippon Television Holdings in October.[11]




## Name[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
 | *Pom Poko* | Isao Takahata | Shang Shang Typhoon | July 16, 1994
 | 86%[103] | 77[104] |
| 1995
 | *Whisper of the Heart* | Yoshifumi Kondō | Hayao Miyazaki | Yuji Nomi | July 15, 1995
 | 94%[105] | 75[106] |
| 1997
 | *Princess Mononoke* | Hayao Miyazaki | Joe Hisaishi | July 12, 1997
 | 93%[107] | 76[108] |
| 1999
 | *My Neighbors the Yamadas* | Isao Takahata | Akiko Yano | July 17, 1999
 | 78%[109] | 75[110] |
| 2001
 | *Spirited Away* | Hayao Miyazaki | Joe Hisaishi | July 20, 2001
 | 96%[111] | 96[112] |
| 2002
 | *The Cat Returns* | Hiroyuki Morita | Reiko Yoshida | Toshio SuzukiNozomu Takahashi
 | Yuji Nomi | July 19, 2002
 | 88%[113] | 70[114] |
| 2004
 | *Howl's Moving Castle* | Hayao Miyazaki | Toshio Suzuki | Joe Hisaishi | November 20, 2004
 | 87%[115] | 82[116] |
| 2006
 | *Tales from Earthsea* | Gorō Miyazaki | Gorō MiyazakiKeiko Niwa
 | Tamiya Terashima
 | July 29, 2006
 | 38%[117] | 47[118] |
| 2008
 | *Ponyo* | Hayao Miyazaki | Joe Hisaishi | July 19, 2008
 | 91%[119] | 86[120] |
| 2010

</fragment>
<fragment>
 | *Arrietty* | Hiromasa Yonebayashi | Hayao MiyazakiKeiko Niwa
 | Cécile Corbel | July 17, 2010
 | 94%[121] | 80[122] |
| 2011
 | *From Up on Poppy Hill* | Gorō Miyazaki | Satoshi Takebe | July 16, 2011
 | 87%[123] | 71[124] |
| 2013
 | *The Wind Rises* | Hayao Miyazaki | Joe Hisaishi | July 20, 2013
 | 88%[125] | 83[126] |
| *The Tale of the Princess Kaguya* | Isao Takahata | Isao TakahataRiko Sakaguchi
 | Yoshiaki Nishimura | November 23, 2013
 | 100%[127] | 89[128] |
| 2014
 | *When Marnie Was There* | Hiromasa Yonebayashi | Hiromasa YonebayashiKeiko NiwaMasashi Ando | Takatsugu Muramatsu
 | July 19, 2014
 | 92%[129] | 72[130] |
| 2016
 | *The Red Turtle* | Michaël Dudok de Wit | Michaël Dudok de WitPascale Ferran | Toshio SuzukiIsao TakahataVincent MaravalPascal CaucheteuxGrégoire Sorlat
 | Laurent Perez del Mar
 | May 18, 2016
 | 93%[131] | 86[132] |
| 2020
 | *Earwig and the Witch* | Gorō Miyazaki | Keiko NiwaEmi Gunji
 | Toshio Suzuki
 | Satoshi Takebe

</fragment>
<fragment>

**Studio Ghibli, Inc.** (Japanese: 株式会社スタジオジブリ, Hepburn: *Kabushiki gaisha Sutajio Jiburi*)[3] is a Japanese animation studio based in Koganei, Tokyo.[4] It has a strong presence in the animation industry and has expanded its portfolio to include various media formats, such as short subjects, television commercials, and two television films. Their work has been well-received by audiences and recognized with numerous awards. Their mascot and most recognizable symbol, the character Totoro, is a giant spirit inspired by raccoon dogs (*tanuki*) and cats[5] from the 1988 film *My Neighbor Totoro*. Among the studio's highest-grossing films are *Spirited Away* (2001), *Howl's Moving Castle* (2004), and *Ponyo* (2008).[6] Studio Ghibli was founded on June 15, 1985, by the directors Hayao Miyazaki and Isao Takahata and producer Toshio Suzuki, after acquiring Topcraft's assets. The studio has also collaborated with video game studios on the visual development of several games.[7]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Studio Ghibli films are mostly hand-drawn using rich water and acrylic paints. The films use traditional methods of making animation where every frame is drawn and colored by hand. Computer animation techniques are used sparingly.[138] All the Studio Ghibli films use bright colors,[139][140] and have a "whimsical and joyful aesthetic".[141] Studio Ghibli’s art style tends to be more of a cozy European style that put a lot of undertones on the background and nature in the scene.[142]


The films often focus on the lives of youth, especially school children. Common themes include the risks posed by progress to tradition,[143] environmentalism and the natural world,[143][141] independent female protagonists,[139] the cost of war, and youth.[140]



## Criticism[edit]


Rayna Denison argues that, despite the feminist themes of Ghibli films, the studio has been reluctant to promote women within the company and regularly overworks its laborers, including on public holidays.[144]


</fragment>
<fragment>

| Year

 | RT | MC |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |

| 1986

| 1988

| *Grave of the Fireflies* | Isao Takahata | Michio Mamiya | 100%[93] | 94[94] |
| 1989

 | 98%[95] | 83[96] |
| 1991

| 1992

| 1993

 | May 5, 1993[A] | 89%[101] | 73[102] |
| 1994

</fragment>
<fragment>
140. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Studio Ghibli Movies – A Deep Analysis of the Themes". *Pop Up Tee*. Archived from the original on November 12, 2021. Retrieved November 12, 2021.
141. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Thomson, Jonny (October 18, 2021). "The philosophy and magic of Hayao Miyazaki's Studio Ghibli". *BigThink*. Archived from the original on November 12, 2021. Retrieved November 12, 2021.
142. **^** Swale, Alistair (July 3, 2015). "Miyazaki Hayao and the Aesthetics of Imagination: Nostalgia and Memory in Spirited Away". *Asian Studies Review*. **39** (3): 413–429. doi:10.1080/10357823.2015.1056086. ISSN 1035-7823. S2CID 141591201.
143. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Barnett, David. "Studio Ghibli films: An indispensable guide". *BBC*. Archived from the original on November 12, 2021. Retrieved November 12, 2021.
144. **^** Denison, Rayna (2023). *Studio Ghibli: An Industrial History*. Palgrave MacMillan. pp. 73–96. ISBN 978-3-031-16843-7.

</fragment>
<fragment>
132. **^** *The Red Turtle*, retrieved August 16, 2022
133. **^** "Earwig and the Witch". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Fandango. Archived from the original on February 12, 2021. Retrieved July 20, 2021.
134. **^** "Earwig and the Witch". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on October 6, 2021. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
135. **^** "The Boy and the Heron". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Retrieved September 9, 2023.
136. **^** "The Boy and the Heron Reviews". *Metacritic*. Retrieved September 9, 2023.
137. **^** Gularte, Alejandra (November 12, 2022). "Grogu Becomes Studio Ghibli-fied in a New Short". *Vulture*. Retrieved January 31, 2023.
138. **^** "How Spirited Away Changed Animation Forever". *Time*. July 20, 2021. Retrieved February 8, 2023.
139. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Alexander, Julia; Frank, Allegra (January 9, 2017). "Studio Ghibli's best movies transcend simple cinema". *Polygon*. Archived from the original on November 12, 2021. Retrieved November 12, 2021.

</fragment>
<fragment>
125. **^** "The Wind Rises (2014)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Fandango Media. Archived from the original on August 17, 2015. Retrieved July 5, 2016. [2014 was the year of the film's U.S. release.]
126. **^** "The Wind Rises". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on July 21, 2014. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
127. **^** "The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Fandango Media. Archived from the original on July 8, 2015. Retrieved July 5, 2016. [2014 was the year of the film's U.S. release.]
128. **^** "The Tale of the Princess Kaguya". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on August 11, 2018. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
129. **^** "When Marnie Was There (2015)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Fandango Media. Archived from the original on July 11, 2015. Retrieved July 5, 2016. [2015 was the year of the film's U.S. release.]
130. **^** "When Marnie Was There". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on July 1, 2018. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
131. **^** *The Red Turtle*, retrieved August 16, 2022

</fragment>
<fragment>

The studio has mainly produced films by Miyazaki, with the second most prolific director being Takahata (most notably with *Grave of the Fireflies*). Other directors who have worked with Studio Ghibli include Yoshifumi Kondō, Hiroyuki Morita, Gorō Miyazaki, and Hiromasa Yonebayashi. Composer Joe Hisaishi has provided the soundtracks for most of Miyazaki's Studio Ghibli films. In their book *Anime Classics Zettai!*, Brian Camp and Julie Davis made note of Michiyo Yasuda as "a mainstay of Studio Ghibli's extraordinary design and production team".[18] At one time the studio was based in Kichijōji, Musashino, Tokyo.[19]


</fragment>
<fragment>
107. **^** "Princess Mononoke (Mononoke-hime) (1999)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Fandango Media. Archived from the original on June 25, 2015. Retrieved July 5, 2016. [1999 was the year of the film's U.S. release.]
108. **^** "Princess Mononoke". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on April 26, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
109. **^** "My Neighbors the Yamadas (1999)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on August 20, 2015. Retrieved December 27, 2015.
110. **^** "My Neighbors the Yamadas". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on May 16, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
111. **^** "Spirited Away (2002)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on June 19, 2015. Retrieved December 27, 2015.[2002 was the year of the film's U.S. release.]
112. **^** "Spirited Away". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on June 14, 2019. Retrieved April 29, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
While not technically Studio Ghibli films, *The Great Adventure of Horus, Prince of the Sun* (1968), *Panda! Go Panda!* (1972), *The Castle of Cagliostro* (1979), *Jarinko Chie* (1981), *Gauche the Cellist* (1982), *Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind* (1984), *The Red Turtle* (2016), *Mary and the Witch's Flower* (2017) and *Modest Heroes* (2018) are sometimes grouped together with the Studio Ghibli library (particularly with the *Ghibli ga Ippai* home video collection released by Walt Disney Studios Japan) due to their ties to the studio.


*Horus* and *Cagliostro* were the feature-length directorial debuts of Isao Takahata and Hayao Miyazaki respectively, and were produced by Toei Animation and TMS Entertainment years before the founding of Studio Ghibli.


*Nausicaä* was directed by Miyazaki at Topcraft, a studio which Miyazaki, Takahata and Toshio Suzuki later purchased and renamed Studio Ghibli. As a result, the film has often been rereleased and marketed as a Studio Ghibli movie.


</fragment>
<fragment>
94. **^** "Grave of the Fireflies". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on May 4, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
95. **^** "Kiki's Delivery Service (1989)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on August 20, 2015. Retrieved July 17, 2020.
96. **^** "Kiki's Delivery Service". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on January 26, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
97. **^** "Only Yesterday (1991)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Fandango Media. Archived from the original on March 31, 2016. Retrieved July 5, 2016.
98. **^** "Only Yesterday (1991)". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on May 16, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
99. **^** "Porco Rosso (Kurenai no buta) (1992)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on August 17, 2015. Retrieved December 27, 2015.
100. **^** "Porco Rosso". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on June 30, 2020. Retrieved April 29, 2022.

</fragment>
</document>

109. **^** "My Neighbors the Yamadas (1999)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on August 20, 2015. Retrieved December 27, 2015.
110. **^** "My Neighbors the Yamadas". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on May 16, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
111. **^** "Spirited Away (2002)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on June 19, 2015. Retrieved December 27, 2015.[2002 was the year of the film's U.S. release.]
112. **^** "Spirited Away". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on June 14, 2019. Retrieved April 29, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
While not technically Studio Ghibli films, *The Great Adventure of Horus, Prince of the Sun* (1968), *Panda! Go Panda!* (1972), *The Castle of Cagliostro* (1979), *Jarinko Chie* (1981), *Gauche the Cellist* (1982), *Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind* (1984), *The Red Turtle* (2016), *Mary and the Witch's Flower* (2017) and *Modest Heroes* (2018) are sometimes grouped together with the Studio Ghibli library (particularly with the *Ghibli ga Ippai* home video collection released by Walt Disney Studios Japan) due to their ties to the studio.


*Horus* and *Cagliostro* were the feature-length directorial debuts of Isao Takahata and Hayao Miyazaki respectively, and were produced by Toei Animation and TMS Entertainment years before the founding of Studio Ghibli.


*Nausicaä* was directed by Miyazaki at Topcraft, a studio which Miyazaki, Takahata and Toshio Suzuki later purchased and renamed Studio Ghibli. As a result, the film has often been rereleased and marketed as a Studio Ghibli movie.


</fragment>
<fragment>
94. **^** "Grave of the Fireflies". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on May 4, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
95. **^** "Kiki's Delivery Service (1989)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on August 20, 2015. Retrieved July 17, 2020.
96. **^** "Kiki's Delivery Service". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on January 26, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
97. **^** "Only Yesterday (1991)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Fandango Media. Archived from the original on March 31, 2016. Retrieved July 5, 2016.
98. **^** "Only Yesterday (1991)". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on May 16, 2022. Retrieved April 29, 2022.
99. **^** "Porco Rosso (Kurenai no buta) (1992)". *Rotten Tomatoes*. Flixster. Archived from the original on August 17, 2015. Retrieved December 27, 2015.
100. **^** "Porco Rosso". *Metacritic.com*. Archived from the original on June 30, 2020. Retrieved April 29, 2022.

</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.content:
Based on the information retrieved, here are the top five Studio Ghibli movies with the highest Rotten Tomatoes ratings and their protagonists:

1. **Grave of the Fireflies (100%)**
   - **Protagonists:** Seita and Setsuko

2. **Only Yesterday (100%)**
   - **Protagonist:** Taeko Okajima

3. **Kiki's Delivery Service (98%)**
   - **Protagonist:** Kiki

4. **Spirited Away (96%)**
   - **Protagonist:** Chihiro Ogino (Sen)

5. **Castle in the Sky (96%)**
   - **Protagonists:** Pazu and Sheeta

These films are highly acclaimed and feature strong, memorable characters that have contributed to their critical success.
